awd_titl_txt: Interfaces and Free Boundaries in Heterogeneous Media
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to develop mathematical tools to study the large-scale features of physical systems with small scale heterogeneities.  The general goal is the derivation of simpler "homogenized" macroscopic laws from complicated microscopic structures.   The focus is on systems involving phase interfaces: motion of fluid-fluid interfaces in porous media, flame propagation in turbulent flow, and, especially, liquid droplet contact lines on rough surfaces.  Although these systems are widely different, their mathematical models have important common features. This project seeks to build a unified set of ideas to study these problems.  The theoretical derivation of macroscopic homogenized laws allows for effective numerical simulations, which have predictive capacity for the associated physical systems.  Deeper understanding of the above-mentioned systems has potential for broader societal benefits through connections with engineering applications, for example, design of water repellant surfaces and liquid droplet-based printing. The project contains potential research opportunities for doctoral students, and, in addition to research activities, the principal investigator will teach and mentor undergraduate and graduate students.

In more precise terms the project is concerned with several partial differential equation (PDE) models of propagating and stationary fronts in heterogeneous media.  The primary goals are of a rigorous analytical nature, but these aims are deeply motivated by physical applications. In broad terms, the project studies (i) singular and anisotropic features which can arise at large scales in periodic media and (ii) problems in random media where novel quantitative estimates need to be developed to control the dependence of PDE solutions on the variations in the underlying medium.  The first part focuses on a set of model free-boundary problems (FBP) which arise in the study of capillary droplets on patterned surfaces and in the study of certain discrete particle systems.  Homogenization of the microscopic structure leads to a new class of FBP. The main objective of this part of the project is to establish rigorously this scaling/homogenization limit and study the well-posedness properties of the limiting FBP. The second part focuses on several physically motivated examples of geometric Hamilton-Jacobi (HJ) equations which lack the classical coercivity assumption of homogenization theory.  The expectation is that coercivity is recovered at large scales through the averaging effect of the random medium, but this has only been rigorously established in a limited number of cases.  The objective of this part of the project is to develop new techniques to study weakly coercive HJ equations; in physical terms this often corresponds to studying interface propagation near a de-pinning transition.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Partial differential equations (PDE) models arise in a wide variety of fundamental models from physics, engineering, biology, and social sciences. Many PDE models deal with large scale or macroscopic phenomena. In order to understand the validity of these models, and derive new models, it is necessary to analyze a ``scaling limit" passing from a model which describes microscopic behaviors in detail, to an ``effective" model which averages out the important microscopic behavior to produce a simplified description of the macroscopic behavior.  In mathematical terms this kind of limit is often referred to as a hydrodynamic limit -- when the microscopic model is a particle system -- or a homogenization limit -- when the microscopic model bakes in a heterogeneous environment.  


Interface and free boundary problems are one particular type of PDE model which features significant additional mathematical challenges as far as classical techniques are concerned.  In particular these problems are often highly nonlinear, and require tools from geometric analysis and nonlinear PDE theory.

This grant funded several projects related homogenization and hydrodynamic scaling limits in models featuring moving and stationary interfaces.  The work made use of and developed novel techniques in the fields of nonlinear elliptic/parabolic PDE, free boundary problems, calculus of variations and probability. The questions studied were motivated by physical applications, the theory of capillarity and wetting, flow in porous media, motion of domain boundaries in random magnetic materials, and flame propagation in heterogeneous media and/or turbulent flows.  Mathematically, many of the questions considered were focused on singular and anisotropic features which can arise at large scales in periodic media, and on problems in random media where novel quantitative estimates need to be developed to control the dependence of PDE solutions on the variations in the underlying medium.

One of the main achievements, funded by the grant, was the introduction of the theory of large scale regularity in homogenization to several free boundary problems. These new developments were then used by the PI, in another work funded by the grant, to study quantitative homogenization of certain shape optimization problems.  These developments will hopefully spur further research on these topics.


Several other results of the grant include works on the following topics: the hydrodynamic limit of an Ising game, the study of pinning and singular effective surface tensions of surface area minimizers in heterogeneous media, a new uniqueness result on singular anisotropic Bernoulli free boundary problems.


During the award period, the grant supported the education and research of Masters and PhD students and several postdoctoral scholars. These researchers have continued their careers in academia or industry.  The project also involved collaborations with junior and senior researchers in France, Japan, and Germany.


Last Modified: 12/05/2024
Modified by: William Feldman
